definition: to finish apprenticeship/to graduate/to send out troops (under a commander)

to go out/to come out/to occur/to produce/to go beyond/to rise/to put forth/to happen/(used after a verb to indicate an outward direction or a positive result)/classifier for dramas, plays, operas etc
variant of 出[chu1] (classifier for plays or chapters of classical novels)
teacher/master/expert/model/army division/(old) troops/to dispatch troops
surname Shi

sentences.english: The second part of the point source of the term for sending good luck and allusions.
sentences.chinese: 第二部分点出师造化一词的来源及其典故。

sentences.english: First day of school and already your child is having a bad year.
sentences.chinese: 结果不尽如人意，才上学的第一天小孩就出师不利。

sentences.english: When you have learned to control the highland , it will be time for you to leave.
sentences.chinese: 当你学会控制高地时，就是你出师的时候了。

sentences.english: I wouldn't have this double handicap make a false start to-night for a million.
sentences.chinese: 今晚，我无论如何不会让这双重困难造成出师不利。

definition: to learn a skill or art
to formally become an apprentice to a master
apprentice/disciple
authentic tradition/handed-down teachings or techniques
to lead troops
to join a guru for instruction
to join up/to enlist (e.g. in the military)
used for 師傅|师傅 (in Taiwan)/master/qualified worker
to enter the Way/to become a Daoist
to impart/to pass on/to teach
to withdraw troops from the front/to return in triumph
to solve or overcome (a difficult problem)/to beat (a video game)
to leave the mountain (of a hermit)/to come out of obscurity to a government job/to take a leading position
to teach/to bequeath
to study diligently/to train assiduously
to enlist/to serve in the army
